                                            By

Jack Shafer


                Rep. Sam Farr announced that he won't run for reelection. | AP

            By 
Steven Shepard
             and 
Elena Schneider

11/12/15 01:44 PM EST
Rep. Sam Farr won't run for reelection in 2016, the California Democrat announced Thursday. 
Farr was first elected in a 1993 special election to succeed former Rep. Leon Panetta, who left the seat to become director of the Office of Management and Budget under Bill Clinton.
Story Continued Below
Farr's decision was first reported by KSBW-TV.
The Monterey-based district is safely Democratic: President Barack Obama won 71 percent of the vote there in 2012, and Farr was reelected last year with 75 percent of the vote.
Panetta's son, Monterey County Deputy District Attorney James Panetta, has been mentioned as a possible successor to Farr. "I've talked to people about it, and it's something I'm seriously considering," the younger Panetta told the Carmel Pine Cone in 2013.
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
title: California Democrat Farr announces retirement
